change.item: Batch update to change repository name, subject links, preferred citation, and user restrictions.

did.abstract: James M. Becker joined the faculty of the Indiana University School of Education in 1971, serving as a member and later as the director (1981-1987) of the IU Social Studies Development Center. During his time at IU, Becker initiated, developed and advocated global education curriculum standards for elementary and secondary school systems in addition to creating teacher training programs. This collection consists largely of publications related to Becker's work in global education as well as his correspondence and administrative files.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Advance notice required.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note/Administrative History
bioghist.p: James M. Becker was born in 1919 in Bridgewater Township, Rice County, Minnesota. He worked on the family farm before leaving to attend the University of Minnesota in 1941. His education was interrupted at age 22, when he was drafted into the military to fight in World War II. During the war, Becker served in the Armored Force, Company C, of the 736 Medium Tank Battalion. Becker later stated that his war experience "sparked [his] deep and abiding interest in world politics, diplomacy, and education as more promising ways to seek to understand and to find ways to resolve international conflicts."1

After the war, Becker resumed his education at the University of Minnesota, receiving a Bachelor of Science degree in 1947 and a Master of Arts degree in 1949. From 1951-1952 Becker took advanced graduate studies at the Teacher's College at Columbia University. He taught political and social science at Winona State College in Minnesota from 1948-1951. Becker then taught at Illinois State University from 1952-1956 before becoming an instructor at Northwestern University from 1964-1965.

In 1971, Becker joined the Social Studies Development Center, School of Education, at Indiana University. From 1971-1975 he directed the Center's Diffusion Project, which was an effort to improve the gathering and dissemination of information tailored to the needs of secondary school personnel.

In 1975, Becker became the director of the Mid-America Program for Global Perspectives in Education (MAP). MAP was designed to improve and expand the emphasis on global studies in schools and other agencies. In 1979-1981, Becker directed the Japan/U.S Textbook Study, in which a team of Japanese and American educators found stereotypes, omissions and outdated facts in both Japanese and American texts. The study's conclusions sparked international debate and also led to Becker's direction of the Netherlands/U.S. Textbook Study.

In 1981, Becker became the director of the Social Studies Development Center at Indiana University. During his tenure Becker wrote numerous works on global education and international understanding, including the seminal work in global education, Schooling for a Global Age, which resulted in Becker becoming known as "The Father of Global Education." Since then, Becker has published numerous books and articles on global education and international understanding. He held leadership roles in several organizations including but not limited to the Social Science Education Consortium, National Council for the Social Studies, Indiana Department of Education, Center for War/Peace Studies, Atlantic Information Center for Teachers, and the Foreign Policy Association. Becker retired from Indiana University in 1988. He died on November 18, 2016 at the age of ninety-seven.
1Kirkwood-Tucker, T. & Goldstein E. (2007). Father of global education: Jim Becker. (p. 11-12).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into four series: Administrative files, Correspondence, Projects, and Publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection is organized into four series, Administrative files, Correspondence, Projects, and Publications. Publications account for the bulk of the materials in the collection.
The Administrative files series contains minutes, executive summaries and reports from several organizations of which James Becker was either a member or leader.
The Correspondence series includes letters from Becker's organizational affiliates and several well known global education pioneers, including Robert Gilmore and Chadwick Alger.

The Projects series contains publications and white papers regarding global education initiatives, curriculum development, teacher education programs, and student materials created and/or directed by James Becker. Individual projects include the Japan/U.S. Textbook Study, International Teacher Education, Foreign Policy Decision Making Simulated Games, and the Diffusion Project.

The Publications series is further organized into two subseries: Publications Authored by Becker and Other. Publications by Becker include articles, books/booklets—including the seminal work Schooling for a Global Age. Also included are Becker's autobiography, An Ordinary Man's Extraordinary Journey book reviews, curriculum standards and guidelines, teaching materials and research proposals. The subseries Other consists of: reports, publications written about James Becker, and publications written by organizations which Becker was affiliated and contributed to the content of the publication as either editor, co-author, or consultant. Featured in this subseries are two biographies on Becker and an article on Becker's reflections on serving in World War II. Also of note are the Mid-America Program for Global Perspectives in Education's Your State in the World publications series. Also included in the Other subseries are reports and photographs of James Becker and the Social Studies Development Center staff and facilities.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Photographs Pulled: 22 photographs and 4 negatives of the Social Studies Development Center staff and facilities were transferred to the Archives Photograph Collection.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Related photographs may be available in the University Archives Photographs Database.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: The donor(s) of this collection have transferred their copyrights for the materials to the Trustees of Indiana University through a Deed of Gift. For more information, please contact the Indiana University Archives staff.

The Indiana University Archives respects the intellectual property rights of others and does not claim any copyrights for non-university records, materials in the public domain, or materials for which we do not hold a Deed of Gift. Responsibility for the determination of the copyright status of these materials rests with those persons wishing to reuse the materials. Researchers are responsible for securing permission from copyright owners and any other rights holders for any reuse of these materials that extends beyond fair use or other statutory limitations.

Digital reproductions of archival materials from the Indiana University Archives are made available for noncommercial educational and research purposes only. If you are the copyright holder for any of the digitized materials and have questions about its inclusion on our site, please contact the Indiana University Archivist.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], James M. Becker papers, Collection C345, Indiana University Archives, Bloomington.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Transferred from James M. Becker to the University Archives, December 2008.
